program/body0/declaration/body/body0/arg.content:
<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXText
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> The simplest way - a string directly
        between opening and closing tags.

<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> Multiple JSXText nodes
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> Each text fragment between elements
        becomes a separate JSXText node.

<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXText + JSXExpressionContainer +
        JSXElement
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> Uses { } to explicitly preserve
        spaces between elements.
Text with spaces and line breaks

<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXText
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> Spaces and line breaks are preserved in
        JSXText, but React normalizes them during rendering.

program/body4/declaration/body/body0/arg.content: 1.4 Text with explicit spaces via expression

<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXElement with JSXAttribute (fallback)
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> String in Error Boundary fallback component.

program/body2/declaration/body/body3/arg.content: Portal content is rendered to document.body (check browser inspector)

<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXExpressionContainer with CallExpression (createPortal)
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> Strings are rendered through a portal to
        another DOM node.

program/body2/declaration/body/body0/arg.content:
<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXElement (Suspense) with JSXAttribute (fallback)
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> String in Suspense fallback component.

program/body1/declaration/body/body1/arg.content:
<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXExpressionContainer with
        ConditionalExpression
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> Conditional expression returns a string
        that is rendered.

program/body1/declaration/body/body0/arg.content:
<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXExpressionContainer with CallExpression
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> Function is called and returns a string
        that is rendered.

program/body1/declaration/body/body1/arg.content:
<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXExpressionContainer with LogicalExpression
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> If the left part is true, the right part
        (string) is rendered.

program/body0/declaration/body/body0/arg.content:
<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXExpressionContainer with BinaryExpression
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> Result of string concatenation is rendered
        as text.

<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXExpressionContainer with StringLiteral
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> String wrapped in curly braces, but
        it's still a string.

program/body0/declaration/body/body1/arg.content:
<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXExpressionContainer with CallExpression
        (MemberExpression)
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> String method returns a new string that
        is rendered.

<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXExpressionContainer with TemplateLiteral
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> Template literal is evaluated and rendered
        as a string.

<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXExpressionContainer with Identifier
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> Variable containing a string is rendered
        as text.

program/body1/declaration/body/body0/arg.content:
Alt text: "Image description" (visible if image fails to
            load or via screen readers)

<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXAttribute with StringLiteral or
        JSXExpressionContainer
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> String in the alt attribute is displayed
        if the image fails to load and is used by screen readers. Visible to
        users.

program/body0/declaration/body/body0/arg.content: aria-label is read by screen readers

<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXAttribute with StringLiteral or
        JSXExpressionContainer
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> aria-label, aria-describedby,
        aria-placeholder and other ARIA attributes are used by screen readers
        and visible to users with disabilities. Subject to localization.
Hover over me to see tooltip

<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXAttribute with StringLiteral
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> String in the title attribute is displayed
        in a tooltip when hovering. Visible to users.

program/body1/declaration/body/body0/arg.content:
<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXElement with JSXText in children
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> String is passed as children of the component.

<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXElement with children
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> String is passed through the children prop.

program/body2/declaration/body/body0/arg.content:
<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXAttribute with StringLiteral
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> String is passed through a prop and
        rendered as visible text. Important: technical props (id, className,
        data-*, etc.) are not subject to localization.

<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXElement (component)

        <element:br></element:br>

        <element:br></element:br>

        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> Function call returning a string.

        <element:br></element:br>

program/body0/declaration/body/body0/arg.content:
<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXText in JSXElement or JSXAttribute (value for input
        type="submit")
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> Button text is visible to users. For
        <input type="submit"> text is set via the value attribute.

<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXText in JSXElement (summary)
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> Text in <summary> is visible to users
        as a clickable heading for an expandable block.

<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXText in JSXElement (legend)
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> Text in <legend> is visible to users
        as a heading for a group of fields.

<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXText in JSXElement
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> Label text for input field is visible to
        users. The htmlFor attribute (technical) is not localized, but text
        inside <label> is subject to localization.

<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXAttribute with StringLiteral or
        JSXExpressionContainer
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> Hint string in input field is visible to
        users before entering text.

<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXText in JSXElement (option)
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> Option text in select is visible to users
        when opening the list. The value attribute (technical) is not localized.

program/body1/declaration/body/body1/arg.content:
<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXAttribute with StringLiteral or JSXExpressionContainer
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> Placeholder and value in textarea are
        visible to users.

program/body0/declaration/body/body0/arg.content:
<element:strong>AST Type:</element:strong> JSXAttribute with StringLiteral
        <element:br></element:br>
        <element:strong>Description:</element:strong> Input field default value is visible to
        users in the field. Used for pre-filled uncontrolled fields.

program/body8/declaration/body/body0/arg.content: 9. Forms - placeholder, value, label, button, option

program/body1/declaration/body/body0/arg.content:
This demonstration shows all possible scenarios and patterns of how
            strings can appear in the final DOM in React and Next.js
            applications and be visible to users on screen (without using
            devtools).

JSXExpressionContainer with various expression types returning
              strings

JSXAttribute with title, alt, aria-label, aria-describedby,
              aria-placeholder and other accessibility attributes
Through props and children that render visible text
Through function calls returning strings for display

Through ternary operators and logical expressions returning
              strings
Through map, forEach and other array methods rendering strings
Placeholder, value, label text, button text, option text
